original.definition: act between parties with a view to reconciling differences

sememes.reasoning: The verb describes an action that aims to bring about a change from a state of disagreement or conflict to a state of agreement or reconciliation between parties, as per the definition 'reconciling differences'.

participants.reasoning: The 'Somebody' who performs the act of interceding, initiating the attempt to change the relationship.
The implicit 'parties' from the definition whose state of disagreement is the target of the intercession, aiming for reconciliation.

Evidentiality.reasoning: Interceding is an observable action or process.

Mood.reasoning: The verb's core meaning is declarative, stating an action or intention.

Modality.reasoning: The frame 'Somebody intercede' implies the agent acts with intention and will to reconcile differences.

Polarity.reasoning: The act of interceding, by aiming to 'reconcile differences', inherently carries a positive sentiment toward resolution and harmony.

Volitionality.reasoning: The frame 'Somebody intercede' clearly indicates a volitional agent performing an intentional action.

Confidence.reasoning: The act of interceding is described as a definite occurrence, even if its outcome is not guaranteed.

Iterativity.reasoning: The lexeme describes a single instance or effort of intervention, which may encompass a series of related actions, but is not characterized by rapid, identical repetitions like 'running'.

participants.reasoning: value_type 'parties.n.01' is not a valid synset in NLTK.

candidates.description: (law) the replacement of one obligation by another by mutual agreement of both parties; usually the replacement of one of the original parties to a contract with the consent of the remaining party (gloss match)
(law) the act of rescinding; the cancellation of a contract and the return of the parties to the positions they would have had if the contract had not been made (gloss match)
sexual intercourse with a person (girl or boy) who has not reached the age of consent (even if both parties participate willingly) (gloss match)
(law) an objection grounded on the judge's relationship to one of the parties (gloss match)
the action of people mingling and coming into contact (gloss match)
a legal action brought against parties who are charged with limiting free competition in the market place (gloss match)
representation of all parties in proportion to their popular vote (gloss match)
a bitter quarrel between two parties (gloss match)
a feud in which members of the opposing parties murder each other (gloss match)
a noisemaker (as at parties or games) that makes a loud noise when you blow through it (gloss match)

a stimulant drug that is chemically related to mescaline and amphetamine and is used illicitly for its euphoric and hallucinogenic effects; it was formerly used in psychotherapy but in 1985 it was declared illegal in the United States (gloss match)
a recreation room for noisy activities (parties or children's play etc) (gloss match)
moderation in expectations (gloss match)
that branch of jurisprudence that studies the rights and obligations of parties entering into contracts (gloss match)
the omission that is made when an editorial change shortens a written passage (gloss match)
a contract which, in the event of a breach by one of the parties, can be considered as several independent agreements expressed in a single instrument (gloss match)
an agreement between two parties that is sanctioned by the court; for example, a company might agree to stop certain questionable practices without admitting guilt (gloss match)
a writ issued by a court at the request of one of the parties to a suit; it requires a witness to bring to court or to a deposition any relevant documents under the witness's control (gloss match)
a summons issued after the filing of a libel or claim directing all parties concerned to show cause why the judgment asked for should not be granted (gloss match)
an agreement between parties (usually arrived at after discussion) fixing obligations of each (gloss match)
a legal document summarizing the agreement between parties (gloss match)
an agreement between parties in a dispute to abide by the decision of an arbiter (gloss match)
a legal document summarizing an agreement between parties in a dispute to abide by the decision of an arbiter (gloss match)
a signed written agreement between two or more parties (nations) to perform some action (gloss match)

an agreement that is not in writing and is not signed by the parties but is a real existing contract that lacks only the formal requirement of a memorandum to render it enforceable in litigation (gloss match)
a song celebrating the joys of drinking; sung at drinking parties (gloss match)

(law) a conference held before the trial begins to bring the parties together to outline discovery proceedings and to define the issues to be tried; more useful in civil than in criminal cases (gloss match)
international negotiations conducted by a mediator who frequently flies back and forth between the negotiating parties (gloss match)
(law) the hearing and determination of a dispute by an impartial referee agreed to by both parties (often used to settle disputes between labor and management) (gloss match)
a temporary accommodation of a disagreement between parties pending a permanent settlement (gloss match)

(law) an agreement or concession made by parties in a judicial proceeding (or by their attorneys) relating to the business before the court; must be in writing unless they are part of the court record (gloss match)
the business of a broker; charges a fee to arrange a contract between two parties (gloss match)
the older of two major political parties in the United States (gloss match)
the younger of two major political parties in the United States; GOP is an acronym for grand old party (gloss match)
a political party organized in opposition to the major parties in a two-party system (gloss match)
an organization formed by merging several groups or parties (gloss match)
a negotiator who acts as a link between parties (gloss match)
(law) a person (usually appointed by a court of law) who liquidates assets or preserves them for the benefit of affected parties (gloss match)
an attractive young woman hired to attend parties and entertain men (gloss match)
a trust created by a court (regardless of the intent of the parties) to benefit a party that has been wrongfully deprived of its rights (gloss match)
a trust created by a court when it is judged that it was the intention of the parties to create a trust (gloss match)
a trust created by the free and deliberate act of the parties involved (usually on the basis of written documentation) (gloss match)
(accounting) a service (less exhaustive than an audit) that provides some assurance to interested parties as to the reliability of financial data (gloss match)
a certificate showing the interests of all parties in a business partnership (gloss match)
a process whereby voters are moved toward nonpartisanship thus weakening the structure of political parties (gloss match)
a basis agreed to by all parties for reaching a mutual understanding (gloss match)
a business relation in which two parties compete to gain customers (gloss match)
a state involving mutual dealings between people or parties or countries (gloss match)
a voluntary union for life (or until divorce) of adult parties of the same sex (gloss match)
harmony of people's opinions or actions or characters (gloss match)

participants.corrected_reasoning: Selected 'relationship.n.03' as its gloss explicitly defines a state involving 'parties', semantically aligning with the concept of entities between whom one might intercede.
